title: 107_hr2579
content: The "Internet Gambling Payments Prohibition Act" aims to address the funding of internet gambling through bank instruments like credit cards and wire transfers. The Act is based on findings that internet gambling causes debt collection issues for financial institutions and is a money laundering risk. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON ACCEPTANCE OF ANY BANK INSTRUMENT FOR INTERNET GAMBLING. No person engaged in a gambling business may knowingly accept credit, electronic fund transfers, checks, or other financial transactions in connection with Internet gambling. The Act prohibits financial transactions related to Internet gambling, with defined terms such as "bets or wagers" encompassing various forms of risking something of value for a chance to win greater value. The Act prohibits financial transactions related to Internet gambling, with "bets or wagers" defined as risking something of value for a chance to win greater value. This excludes bona fide business transactions governed by securities laws or transactions on a contract market designated by the Commodity Exchange Act. The Commodity Exchange Act excludes certain financial transactions, such as over-the-counter derivatives, indemnity or guarantee contracts, insurance contracts, and participation in specific types of games or contests that are not solely dependent on the outcome of a single sporting event or individual performance. The term "gambling business" refers to a business conducted at a gambling establishment that involves outcomes determined by statistical results of sporting events and offers predetermined prizes to participants. A gambling business involves the placing, receiving, or making of bets, conducted by individuals who manage or own the business, operating for over 10 days or generating $2,000 in revenue within 24 hours. The term "Internet" refers to the global network of interconnected data networks, while "Internet gambling" involves placing bets or wagers using the Internet. Additionally, terms like "credit", "creditor", and "credit card" are defined in the Truth in Lending Act. The term "electronic fund transfer" includes fund transfers covered by Article 4 of the Uniform Commercial Code. The term "financial institution" is defined in the Electronic Fund Transfer Act. The terms "money transmitting business" and "money transmitting service" are defined in title 31, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction to prevent violations of this section. The United States, through the Attorney General, may institute proceedings. The United States, through the Attorney General, may institute proceedings to prevent violations of this section. The district court may enter an injunction against any person to restrain a violation, in accordance with Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. State attorney generals can also take action against violations in their respective states. Proceedings can be initiated by the United States or State attorney generals to prevent violations of this section. The district court may issue an injunction to restrain violations, following Rule 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The United States has enforcement authority for violations on Indian lands, while Tribal-State compacts specify enforcement authorities. District courts can issue temporary restraining orders in exigent circumstances. The United States can obtain a temporary restraining order against individuals violating the law, with potential criminal penalties of fines or imprisonment. Courts may also issue permanent injunctions against those convicted, prohibiting them from engaging in illegal betting activities. No liability for financial intermediaries in illegal betting transactions. No liability for financial intermediaries in illegal betting transactions. Exception for knowing participation in a gambling business. This paragraph exempts individuals involved in gambling businesses or knowingly participating in gambling activities from liability. SEC. 4. INTERNET GAMBLING IN OR THROUGH FOREIGN JURISDICTIONS. In deliberations with other countries on money laundering, corruption, and crime, the US Government should promote cooperation in identifying if Internet gambling is used for illegal activities, advance policies for enforcement, and encourage the study of Internet gambling in money laundering by the Financial Action Task Force. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide an annual report to Congress on discussions with other countries regarding Internet gambling issues. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide an annual report to Congress on discussions with other countries regarding Internet gambling issues. Enforcement actions will be taken. Section 8 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to allow Federal banking agencies to prohibit insured depository institutions from engaging in activities related to internet gambling, such as extending credit to violators of the Internet Gambling Payments Prohibition Act. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to allow Federal banking agencies to prohibit insured depository institutions from engaging in activities related to internet gambling, including paying, transferring, or collecting on any check with the knowledge of a violation of the Internet Gambling Payments Prohibition Act.
